title: Enshrouded and the Dragon Hunt

author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: Having found and defeated the fell cyclops the week before, allowing us to raise the flame level to seven, we were now faced with the need for a fell dragon youngling head to get us to the eighth, …
text: Having found and defeated the fell cyclops the week before, allowing us to raise the flame level to seven, we were now faced with the need for a fell dragon youngling head to get us to the eighth, and current final, flame level in Enshrouded. Welcome to Enshrouded The game was pretty clear about what it expected out of us.  Having his this point, every time we logged in now we got what amounted to an ad for the dragon event, a big The Dragon Rises graphic on our screens. Peak dragon ad campaign The journal came right and told us that we needed to head through Everfrore Keep, right up the slope from our frosty base, pass through that and up the mountain until we reached Howling Peak, where we would challenge the beast. Seemed simple enough, right?  Just another dragon fight, right?  At one past date a much younger and naive version of myself declared that dragon fights were special.  That was a lot of dragon fights ago. But we knew where to head when we met up this past Saturday.  We got out food and frost protection together and fast traveled to our base up above the frost line where we would start our trek to the peak.  This was also where our timers started, a little over 30 minutes for each of us, which was the amount of time we could be exposed to the cold at altitude.  But on the map the Howling Peak looked very close.  How long could it take? So we headed up into Everfrore Keep, up the way we went previously, up and around and into the shroud covered portion, fighting mobs along the way, stopping to grab treasure from chests we spotted, getting lost or falling off a ledge now and then, requiring us to backtrack or go find whoever slipped. It took a while to get to the back side of the keep and onto the mountain proper.  Then there was a path to follow, and mobs to fight, and the inevitable swing and grapple challenge which is pretty much guaranteed to cause a five minute delay as everybody figures out in their own way how to get past it. Grapple, swing, let go, then grab the next grapple and get pulled up There were more mobs on the far side, including another cyclops mini boss that we needed to defeat. Always somebody getting in our way But we had gotten far enough up the mountain that, as the sun set… so we had to do this in the dark… we could at least see the dragon, circling in a red sky, waiting for us. First glimpse of the dragon We entered the caves behind the cyclops which were icy and had more mobs and another set of ways to grapple or climb up until we finally made it past the last few mobs, came out of the cave, and saw our foe much closer than before. Emerging into the light to see the dragon And then we all died. We didn’t die to the dragon.  We died because our frost protection timer ran down and, like the shroud timer in the game, once it hits zero you simply die.  There is no slow freezing to death, no taking damage as you race for warmth.  It is just timer hits zero, then you’re on the death screen. Actually, only Potshot and I died because Ula had fallen to her death on the trip up and, on being revived, found her frost timer back up past the 30 minute mark.  Still, we were in a bit of a fix.  There was a flame shrine there, but when I revived I had a one minute frost timer, so died pretty quickly. Potshot, in a moment of clarity, laid down a flame shrine there at the cave.  We could now fast travel away, warm up, then fast travel back and carry on. The flame shrine planted So we did just that, headed back to a fast travel point in the warmth, which reset our frost timer, then returned to seek combat with the dragon… who still seemed to be kind of far away. Out at the ledge past the flame shrine, a message would pop up telling us how to attack the dragon. Instructions revealed Stun arrows, eh?  So we went back to base again, manufactured a big pile of stun arrows, traveled back, then stood at the end of the platform there and tried to shoot the dragon. It wasn’t happening.  We were too far away.  We needed to get closer… but there was a big honking gap between us and where the dragon circled.  Potshot glided down to a peak in between us and the dragon to see if he could reach it from there, but no luck. Potshot out in front of us, but not far enough We decided we could reach an outcropping on the face of the peaks leading up to the dragon, but once we glided there we found no path up.  But in this mutable world, we had options… and picks… so we decided to tunnel up to the dragon, digging through the granite to get within range. We dug upwards, to bring ourselves to the level of the dragon, then closer to it, poking holes along the way to track our progress.  It took some work, but we kept digging. In our tunnel up to the dragon And from our positions in the tunnel, through the holes, we peppered the dragon with arrows, slowly chipping away at it.  It wasn’t easy.  The dragon wasn’t fooled and flew over and breathed its fire down the tunnels, roasting us multiple times, but never getting all three of us at once.  So through bloodly minded persistence we managed to take the dragon down. Before the fallen dragon We looted its head, went back to our base and upgraded the flame to level eight and everything was wonderful.  We had succeeded. Flame level 8 achieved There was just one problem… I had been back at base restocking supplies when the final blow landed.  I had not gotten credit for the kill and did not get the achievement. So I had to ask everybody if we could do it again.  We decided to do a bit of research on how the fight should be done, having done it without any guidance now, and we came up with a bunch of posts and videos about the fight, including this one where the guy defeats the dragon in about a minute. Sure, that person probably had just the right spec and gear and had obviously practiced it.  But we’d be happy maybe doing it… three minutes? Once revelation from the research was the realization that there were thermals rising around where the dragon hangs out, so you can just glide over there, no problem.  I was able to do it on the first try, no issue. Gliding over to the dragon There was all sorts of advice, so we decided to reconvene the next day and kill the dragon the “right” way, out there on the big circular path that he flies around. So the next day we got ourselves loaded up, lots of food and arrows and whatever, then fast traveled to the flame shrine up at Howling Peak, ready to take it straight to the dragon. The flame shrine was given an appropriate name And it was a disaster.  We could survive for a while, but it is a very mobile fight and you have to get out of the way of the breath weapon or you’re dead.  There are lots of thermals rising that will carry you while you glide, so you can get out of the way, but you can’t fight and glide… well, I can’t anyway.  Potshot respec’d to ranger and he can float and shoot a bit, but that wasn’t going to get us there. Still, in the face of many deaths we had managed to chip away at him, bringing him down about a third of his health… and then we were all dead at the same interval and with nobody up there engaged, the dragon reset back to full health. That was bullshit and we were pissed.  Right then we gave up on doing this “right” and went back to our outcropping and started tunneling again.  Like the dragon, changes to the land outside the lines of your flame shrine get reset if left unwatched, so we had to get out the picks and dig dig dig. Once we got up the mountain we started opening up galleries to shoot from, with sections of stone left in place to hide behind and it was one. Taking a shot at the dragon Potshot, the ranger, who did the most damage with the bow, carried the weight of the effort.  With the ranger skill that zooms in your view when you draw your bow, he was able to score early and often. Ula and I would shoot, then dig some more, trying to find an optimum spot to allow us to get in some damage.  We eschewed the whole stun arrow thing and just pelted him whenever we could. Firing on the dragon’s flank as he passes And down he fell after a large expenditure of arrows and a few deaths on our part. We might not have done it the right way, but we did it our way.  We went down to loot him again.  We now have a few spare dragon heads for decoration.  And, of course, I got the achievement in Steam this time, thanks to the team. The achievement complete That is not the rarest achievement I have earned in the game though.  That honor belongs to the one for finding all the obelisks in the Albaneve Summits.  And the rarest one on the list… which only 0.2% of players have… is finding all the flame shrines up in the summits.  I’ll have to work on that one. Now, of course, there is the question of what to do next.  All three of us are at the level cap now, which sits at level 35, and we have defeated what appears to be the final boss.  There are still quests in our journal round up, achievements to chase, places to explore, and shroud roots and elixir wells to track down, each of which grants another ability point to work with. And then there is base building.  Potshot has been out running down quests that yield new building materials.  Meanwhile, the last big update made building a bit more interesting. So there are things to do, and there is more content coming this year from the devs.  They want to launch in about a year, so they will be driving to complete their vision.  We will see what comes next.
html:
Having found and defeated the fell cyclops the week before, allowing us to raise the flame level to seven, we were now faced with the need for a fell dragon youngling head to get us to the eighth, and current final, flame level in Enshrouded.

Welcome to Enshrouded

The game was pretty clear about what it expected out of us.  Having his this point, every time we logged in now we got what amounted to an ad for the dragon event, a big The Dragon Rises graphic on our screens.

Peak dragon ad campaign

The journal came right and told us that we needed to head through Everfrore Keep, right up the slope from our frosty base, pass through that and up the mountain until we reached Howling Peak, where we would challenge the beast.

Seemed simple enough, right?  Just another dragon fight, right?  At one past date a much younger and naive version of myself declared that dragon fights were special.  That was a lot of dragon fights ago.

But we knew where to head when we met up this past Saturday.  We got out food and frost protection together and fast traveled to our base up above the frost line where we would start our trek to the peak.  This was also where our timers started, a little over 30 minutes for each of us, which was the amount of time we could be exposed to the cold at altitude.  But on the map the Howling Peak looked very close.  How long could it take?

So we headed up into Everfrore Keep, up the way we went previously, up and around and into the shroud covered portion, fighting mobs along the way, stopping to grab treasure from chests we spotted, getting lost or falling off a ledge now and then, requiring us to backtrack or go find whoever slipped.

It took a while to get to the back side of the keep and onto the mountain proper.  Then there was a path to follow, and mobs to fight, and the inevitable swing and grapple challenge which is pretty much guaranteed to cause a five minute delay as everybody figures out in their own way how to get past it.

Grapple, swing, let go, then grab the next grapple and get pulled up

There were more mobs on the far side, including another cyclops mini boss that we needed to defeat.

Always somebody getting in our way

But we had gotten far enough up the mountain that, as the sun set… so we had to do this in the dark… we could at least see the dragon, circling in a red sky, waiting for us.

First glimpse of the dragon

We entered the caves behind the cyclops which were icy and had more mobs and another set of ways to grapple or climb up until we finally made it past the last few mobs, came out of the cave, and saw our foe much closer than before.

Emerging into the light to see the dragon

And then we all died.

We didn’t die to the dragon.  We died because our frost protection timer ran down and, like the shroud timer in the game, once it hits zero you simply die.  There is no slow freezing to death, no taking damage as you race for warmth.  It is just timer hits zero, then you’re on the death screen.

Actually, only Potshot and I died because Ula had fallen to her death on the trip up and, on being revived, found her frost timer back up past the 30 minute mark.  Still, we were in a bit of a fix.  There was a flame shrine there, but when I revived I had a one minute frost timer, so died pretty quickly.

Potshot, in a moment of clarity, laid down a flame shrine there at the cave.  We could now fast travel away, warm up, then fast travel back and carry on.

The flame shrine planted

So we did just that, headed back to a fast travel point in the warmth, which reset our frost timer, then returned to seek combat with the dragon… who still seemed to be kind of far away.

Out at the ledge past the flame shrine, a message would pop up telling us how to attack the dragon.

Instructions revealed

Stun arrows, eh?  So we went back to base again, manufactured a big pile of stun arrows, traveled back, then stood at the end of the platform there and tried to shoot the dragon.

It wasn’t happening.  We were too far away.  We needed to get closer… but there was a big honking gap between us and where the dragon circled.  Potshot glided down to a peak in between us and the dragon to see if he could reach it from there, but no luck.

Potshot out in front of us, but not far enough

We decided we could reach an outcropping on the face of the peaks leading up to the dragon, but once we glided there we found no path up.  But in this mutable world, we had options… and picks… so we decided to tunnel up to the dragon, digging through the granite to get within range.

We dug upwards, to bring ourselves to the level of the dragon, then closer to it, poking holes along the way to track our progress.  It took some work, but we kept digging.

In our tunnel up to the dragon

And from our positions in the tunnel, through the holes, we peppered the dragon with arrows, slowly chipping away at it.  It wasn’t easy.  The dragon wasn’t fooled and flew over and breathed its fire down the tunnels, roasting us multiple times, but never getting all three of us at once.  So through bloodly minded persistence we managed to take the dragon down.

Before the fallen dragon

We looted its head, went back to our base and upgraded the flame to level eight and everything was wonderful.  We had succeeded.

Flame level 8 achieved

There was just one problem… I had been back at base restocking supplies when the final blow landed.  I had not gotten credit for the kill and did not get the achievement.

So I had to ask everybody if we could do it again.  We decided to do a bit of research on how the fight should be done, having done it without any guidance now, and we came up with a bunch of posts and videos about the fight, including this one where the guy defeats the dragon in about a minute.

Sure, that person probably had just the right spec and gear and had obviously practiced it.  But we’d be happy maybe doing it… three minutes?

Once revelation from the research was the realization that there were thermals rising around where the dragon hangs out, so you can just glide over there, no problem.  I was able to do it on the first try, no issue.

Gliding over to the dragon

There was all sorts of advice, so we decided to reconvene the next day and kill the dragon the “right” way, out there on the big circular path that he flies around.

So the next day we got ourselves loaded up, lots of food and arrows and whatever, then fast traveled to the flame shrine up at Howling Peak, ready to take it straight to the dragon.

The flame shrine was given an appropriate name

And it was a disaster.  We could survive for a while, but it is a very mobile fight and you have to get out of the way of the breath weapon or you’re dead.  There are lots of thermals rising that will carry you while you glide, so you can get out of the way, but you can’t fight and glide… well, I can’t anyway.  Potshot respec’d to ranger and he can float and shoot a bit, but that wasn’t going to get us there.

Still, in the face of many deaths we had managed to chip away at him, bringing him down about a third of his health… and then we were all dead at the same interval and with nobody up there engaged, the dragon reset back to full health.

That was bullshit and we were pissed.  Right then we gave up on doing this “right” and went back to our outcropping and started tunneling again.  Like the dragon, changes to the land outside the lines of your flame shrine get reset if left unwatched, so we had to get out the picks and dig dig dig.

Once we got up the mountain we started opening up galleries to shoot from, with sections of stone left in place to hide behind and it was one.

Taking a shot at the dragon

Potshot, the ranger, who did the most damage with the bow, carried the weight of the effort.  With the ranger skill that zooms in your view when you draw your bow, he was able to score early and often.

Ula and I would shoot, then dig some more, trying to find an optimum spot to allow us to get in some damage.  We eschewed the whole stun arrow thing and just pelted him whenever we could.

Firing on the dragon’s flank as he passes

And down he fell after a large expenditure of arrows and a few deaths on our part.

We might not have done it the right way, but we did it our way.  We went down to loot him again.  We now have a few spare dragon heads for decoration.  And, of course, I got the achievement in Steam this time, thanks to the team.

The achievement complete

That is not the rarest achievement I have earned in the game though.  That honor belongs to the one for finding all the obelisks in the Albaneve Summits.  And the rarest one on the list… which only 0.2% of players have… is finding all the flame shrines up in the summits.  I’ll have to work on that one.

Now, of course, there is the question of what to do next.  All three of us are at the level cap now, which sits at level 35, and we have defeated what appears to be the final boss.  There are still quests in our journal round up, achievements to chase, places to explore, and shroud roots and elixir wells to track down, each of which grants another ability point to work with.

And then there is base building.  Potshot has been out running down quests that yield new building materials.  Meanwhile, the last big update made building a bit more interesting.

So there are things to do, and there is more content coming this year from the devs.  They want to launch in about a year, so they will be driving to complete their vision.  We will see what comes next.
